translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When Joseph told his father: "O my father, I saw eleven stars and the sun and the moon bowing before me in homage,"

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Remember when Yusuf (Joseph) said to his father, “O my father! I saw eleven stars and the sun and the moon – I saw them prostrating to me.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: When Joseph said to his father, 'Father, I saw eleven stars, and the sun and the moon; I saw them bowing down before me.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Recall what time Yusufj said unto his father:, y father! verily have seen eleven stars and the sun and the moon; I have seen them prostrating themselves unto me.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: (Remember) when Yusuf (Joseph) said to his father: "O my father! Verily, I saw (in a dream) eleven stars and the sun and the moon, I saw them prostrating themselves to me."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: When Joseph said to his father, “O my father, I saw eleven planets, and the sun, and the moon; I saw them bowing down to me.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Call to mind when Joseph said to his father: "My father! I saw (in a dream) eleven stars and the sun and the moon: I saw them prostrating themselves before me."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: (Remember) when Yusuf said to his father: "O my father! Verily, I saw (in a dream) eleven stars and the sun and the moon - I saw them prostrating themselves to me."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: When Joseph said unto his father: O my father! Lo! I saw in a dream eleven planets and the sun and the moon, I saw them prostrating themselves unto me.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When Joseph said to his father, ‘Father! I saw eleven planets, and the sun and the moon: I saw them prostrating themselves before me,’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: When Joseph said to his father: 'Father, I saw eleven planets, and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating themselves before me'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Of these stories mention] when Joseph said to his father, "O my father, indeed I have seen [in a dream] eleven stars and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating to me."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When Joseph said, "Father, in my dream I saw eleven stars, the sun and the moon prostrating before me,"

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: When Yusuf said to his father: O my father! surely I saw eleven stars and the sun and the moon-- I saw them making obeisance to me.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: When Joseph told his father, "My father, I saw eleven stars, and the sun and moon: I saw them prostrate themselves before me,"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Behold! Joseph said to his father: "O my father! I did see eleven stars and the sun and the moon: I saw them prostrate themselves to me!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: In the story of Joseph and his brothers are lessons for those who inquire.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Indeed in Yusuf and his brothers are signs* for those who enquire**. (* Of the truthfulness of Prophet Mohammed – peace and blessings be upon him. ** The Jews who enquired about their story.)

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: (In Joseph and his brethren were signs for those who ask questions.)

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Assuredly in Yusuf and his brethren there have been signs for the inquirers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Verily, in Yusuf (Joseph) and his brethren, there were Ayat (proofs, evidences, verses, lessons, signs, revelations, etc.) for those who ask.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: In Joseph and his brothers are lessons for the seekers.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Verily in the story of Joseph and his brothers there are many signs for those who inquire (about the truth).

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Verily, in Yusuf and his brethren there were Ayat for those who ask.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Verily in Joseph and his brethren are signs (of Allah's Sovereignty) for the inquiring.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: In Joseph and his brothers there are certainly signs for the seekers.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Indeed, in Joseph and his brothers there were signs for those who inquire.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Certainly were there in Joseph and his brothers signs for those who ask,

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: In the story of Joseph and his brothers, there is evidence (of the truth) for those who seek to know.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: Certainly in Yusuf and his brothers there are signs for the inquirers.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Surely, in Joseph and his brothers there are signs for the inquirers.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Verily in Joseph and his brethren are signs (or symbols) for seekers (after Truth).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "Surely Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we," (said his half brothers) "even though we are a well-knit band. Our father is surely in the wrong.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: When they said, “Indeed Yusuf and his brother* are dearer to our father than we are, and we are one group; undoubtedly our father is, clearly, deeply engrossed in love.” (* Of the same mother.)

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: When they said, 'Surely Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we, though we are a band. Surely our father is in manifest error.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Recall what time they said: surely Yusuf and his brother are dearer to our father than we, whereas we are company; verily our father is in error manifest.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: When they said: "Truly, Yusuf (Joseph) and his brother (Benjamin) are loved more by our father than we, but we are 'Usbah (a strong group). Really, our father is in a plain error.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: When they said, “Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we are, although we are a whole group. Our father is obviously in the wrong.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And call to mind when the brothers of Joseph conferred together and said: "Surely Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we are, although we are a group of so many. Our father is clearly mistaken.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: When they said: "Truly, Yusuf and his brother are dearer to our father than we, while we are `Usbah (a group). Really, our father is in a plain error."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: When they said: Verily Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we are, many though we be. Lo! our father is in plain aberration.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When they said, ‘Surely Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than [the rest of] us, though we are a hardy band. Our father is indeed in manifest error.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They said: 'Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than ourselves, even though we are many. Truly, our father is obviously wrong.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: When they said, "Joseph and his brother are more beloved to our father than we, while we are a clan. Indeed, our father is in clear error.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph's brothers said to one another, "There is no doubt that Joseph and his brother are more loved by our father, even though we are all his offspring. He (our father) is certainly in manifest error."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: When they said: Certainly Yusuf and his brother are dearer to our father than we, though we are a (stronger) company; most surely our father is in manifest error:

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: They said [to each other], "Surely Joseph and his brother [Benjamin] are dearer to our father than ourselves, although we are a band. Truly, our father is clearly mistaken.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: They said: "Truly Joseph and his brother are loved more by our father than we: But we are a goodly body! really our father is obviously wandering (in his mind)!

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Let us kill Joseph or cast him in some distant land so that we may get our father's exclusive affection; then play innocent."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: “Kill Yusuf or throw him somewhere in the land, so that your father’s attention may be directed only towards you, and then after it you may again become righteous!”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Kill you Joseph, or cast him forth into some land, that your father's face may be free for you, and thereafter you may be a righteous people.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Slay Yusuf or cast him forth to some land; your father's countenance will be free for you, and ye shall be thereafter a people favoured.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: "Kill Yusuf (Joseph) or cast him out to some (other) land, so that the favour of your father may be given to you alone, and after that you will be righteous folk (by intending repentance before committing the sin)."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: “Kill Joseph, or throw him somewhere in the land, and your father‘s attention will be yours. Afterwards, you will be decent people.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: So either kill Joseph or cast him into some distant land so that your father's attention may become exclusively yours. And after so doing become righteous."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: "Kill Yusuf or cast him out to some (other) land, so that the favor of your father may be given to you alone, and after that you will be righteous folk."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (One said): Kill Joseph or cast him to some (other) land, so that your father's favour may be all for you, and (that) ye may afterward be righteous folk.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: ‘Kill Joseph or cast him away into some [distant] land, so that your father’s attention may be exclusively towards you, and thereafter you may become a righteous lot.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: (Let us) kill Joseph, or cast him away in some (far off) land, so that your father's face will be left for you, and afterwards you will be a righteous nation'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Kill Joseph or cast him out to [another] land; the countenance of your father will [then] be only for you, and you will be after that a righteous people."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Some of them suggested, "Let us kill Joseph or leave him somewhere far away from the presence of our father. Only then shall we receive equal treatment and thereafter can become righteous people".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: Slay Yusuf or cast him (forth) into some land, so that your father's regard may be exclusively for you, and after that you may be a righteous people.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Therefore, let us put Joseph to death or cast him away to some [far-off] land, so that our father's attention should turn only to us, and you can thereafter become a righteous people."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "Slay ye Joseph or cast him out to some (unknown) land, that so the favour of your father may be given to you alone: (there will be time enough) for you to be righteous after that!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: One of them said: "If you must do so, then do not kill Joseph, but throw him into an unused well. Some passing caravan may rescue him."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: A speaker among them said, “Do not kill Yusuf – and drop him into a dark well so that some traveller may come and take him away, if you have to.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: One of them said, 'No, kill not Joseph, but cast him into the bottom of the pit and some traveller will pick him out, if you do aught.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Said a speaker from among them; slay not Yusuf, but cast him into the bottom of a well, some of the caravan will take him up--if ye must be doing.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: One from among them said: "Kill not Yusuf (Joseph), but if you must do something, throw him down to the bottom of a well, he will be picked up by some caravan of travellers."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: One of them said, “Do not kill Joseph, but throw him into the bottom of the well; some caravan may pick him up—if you must do something.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Thereupon one of them said: "Do not kill Joseph, but if you are bent upon doing something, cast him down to the bottom of some dark pit, perhaps some caravan passing by will take him out of it."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: One from among them said: "Kill not Yusuf, but if you must do something, throw him down to the bottom of a well; he will be picked up by some caravan of travelers."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: One among them said: Kill not Joseph but, if ye must be doing, fling him into the depth of the pit; some caravan will find him.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: One of them said, ‘Do not kill Joseph, but cast him into the recess of a well so that some caravan may pick him up, if you are to do [anything].’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: One of them said: 'No, do not kill Joseph, if you do anything, cast him into a dark pit, a traveler will pick him up'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Said a speaker among them, "Do not kill Joseph but throw him into the bottom of the well; some travelers will pick him up - if you would do [something]."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: One of them said, "Do not kill Joseph, but if you must, throw him into a dark well so that perhaps some caravan will take him away."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: A speaker from among them said: Do not slay Yusuf, and cast him down into the bottom of the pit if you must do (it), (so that) some of the travellers may pick him up.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: One of them said, "Do not kill Joseph, but if you must do something, cast him into the bottom of a well; some of the travellers will pick him up."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Said one of them: "Slay not Joseph, but if ye must do something, throw him down to the bottom of the well: he will be picked up by some caravan of travellers."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (Then going to their father) they said: "O father, why don't you trust us with Joseph? We are in fact his well-wishers.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: They said, “O our father! What is the matter with you that you do not trust us with Yusuf, although we are in fact his well-wishers?”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They said, 'Father, what ails thee, that thou trustest us not with Joseph? Surely we are his sincere well-wishers.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: They said: our father! wherefore thou intrustest us not with Yusuf, whereas verily we are his well-wishers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: They said: "O our father! Why do you not trust us with Yusuf (Joseph), - when we are indeed his well-wishers?"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: They said, “Father, why do you not trust us with Joseph, although we care for him?”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: After so deciding they said to their father: "Why is it that you do not trust us regarding Joseph although we are his true well-wishers?"

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: They said: "O our father! Why do you not trust us with Yusuf though we are indeed his well-wishers"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: They said: O our father! Why wilt thou not trust us with Joseph, when lo! we are good friends to him?

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They said, ‘Father! Why is it that you do not trust us with Joseph? We are indeed his well-wishers.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They said: 'Father, what is the matter with you, do you not trust us with Joseph? Indeed, we are sincere advisors.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: They said, "O our father, why do you not entrust us with Joseph while indeed, we are to him sincere counselors?

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Then they asked their father, "Why do you not trust us with Joseph? We are his well-wishers.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: They said: O our father! what reason have you that you do not trust in us with respect to Yusuf? And most surely we are his sincere well-wishers:

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: They said to their father, "Why do you not trust us with Joseph? We are indeed his well-wishers.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: They said: "O our father! why dost thou not trust us with Joseph,- seeing we are indeed his sincere well-wishers?

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: So, when they took him out they planned to throw him into an unused well. We revealed to Joseph: "You will tell them (one day) of this deed when they will not apprehend it."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: So when they went with him, and agreed to put him in the bottom of the well, and We revealed to him, 'Thou shalt tell them of this their doing when they are unaware.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: So when they took him away, and resolved to place him in the bottom of the well, We Revealed unto him: surely thou wilt declare unto them this their affair, while they shall perceive not.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So, when they took him away, they all agreed to throw him down to the bottom of the well, and We inspired in him:"Indeed, you shall (one day) inform them of this their affair, when they know (you) not."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: So they went away with him, and agreed to put him at the bottom of the well. And We inspired him, “You will inform them of this deed of theirs when they are unaware.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: So when they went away with Joseph and decided to cast him in the bottom of the dark pit, We revealed to Joseph: "Surely a time will come when you will remind them of their deed. They know nothing about the consequence of what they are doing."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: So, when they took him away, they all agreed to throw him down to the bottom of the well, and We revealed to him: "Indeed, you shall (one day) inform them of this their affair, when they know (you) not."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Then, when they led him off, and were of one mind that they should place him in the depth of the pit, We inspired in him: Thou wilt tell them of this deed of theirs when they know (thee) not.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: So when they took him away and conspired to put him into the recess of a well, We revealed to him, ‘[A day will come when] you will surely inform them about this affair of theirs while they are not aware [of your identity].’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: When they went with him, they agreed to put him in the bottom of a well. We revealed to him: 'You shall tell them of what they did when they are not aware (it is you)'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So when they took him [out] and agreed to put him into the bottom of the well... But We inspired to him, "You will surely inform them [someday] about this affair of theirs while they do not perceive [your identity]."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When they took Joseph with them, they agreed to throw him into the well. We revealed to Joseph that (sometime) in the future at a time when they would not recognize him, he would remind them of all this.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So when they had gone off with him and agreed that they should put him down at the bottom of the pit, and We revealed to him: You will most certainly inform them of this their affair while they do not perceive.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: And so, when they went away with him, they decided to cast him into the dark depths of a well. Then We revealed to him Our will, "You shall [one day] tell them of this deed of theirs, when they do not realize who you are."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So they did take him away, and they all agreed to throw him down to the bottom of the well: and We put into his heart (this Message): 'Of a surety thou shalt (one day) tell them the truth of this their affair while they know (thee) not'

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: And said: "We went racing with one another and left Joseph to guard our things when a wolf devoured him. But you will not believe us even though we tell the truth."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Saying, “O our father! We went far ahead while racing, and left Yusuf near our resources – therefore the wolf devoured him; and you will not believe us although we may be truthful.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They said, 'Father, we went running races, and left Joseph behind with our things; so the wolf ate him. But thou wouldst never believe us, though we spoke truly.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: They said: our father! we went off competing, and left Yusuf by our stuff, so a wolf devoured him; and thou wilt put no credence in us, even though we are the truth-tellers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: They said:"O our father! We went racing with one another, and left Yusuf (Joseph) by our belongings and a wolf devoured him; but you will never believe us even when we speak the truth."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: They said, “O father, we went off racing one another, and left Joseph by our belongings; and the wolf ate him. But you will not believe us, even though we are being truthful.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: and said: "Father! We went racing with one another and left Joseph behind with our things, and then a wolf came and ate him up. We know that you will not believe us howsoever truthful we might be."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: They said: "O our father! We went racing with one another, and left Yusuf by our belongings and a wolf devoured him; but you will never believe us even when we speak the truth."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Saying: O our father! We went racing one with another, and left Joseph by our things, and the wolf devoured him, and thou believest not our saying even when we speak the truth.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They said, ‘Father! We had gone racing and left Joseph with our things, whereat the wolf ate him. But you will not believe us even if we spoke truly.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They said: 'We went racing and left Joseph with our things. The wolf devoured him, but you will not believe us, though we speak the truth'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: They said, "O our father, indeed we went racing each other and left Joseph with our possessions, and a wolf ate him. But you would not believe us, even if we were truthful."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: and saying, "Father, we went playing and left Joseph with our belongings. A wild-beast came and devoured him. We realize that you will not believe us even though we are telling the truth".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: They said: O our father! surely we went off racing and left Yusuf by our goods, so the wolf devoured him, and you will not believe us though we are truthful.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: They said, "Father, we went off racing and left Joseph with our belongings, and the wolf devoured him. But you will not believe us, even though we are telling the truth."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: They said: "O our father! We went racing with one another, and left Joseph with our things; and the wolf devoured him.... But thou wilt never believe us even though we tell the truth."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: A caravan happened to pass, and sent the water-carrier to bring water from the well. He let down his bucket (and pulled Joseph up with it). "What luck," said the man; "here is a boy;" and they hid him as an item of merchandise; but what they did was known to God.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Then came travellers, and they sent one of them, a water-drawer, who let down his bucket. 'Good news!' he said. 'Here is a young man.' So they hid him as merchandise; but God knew what they were doing.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And a caravan came, and they sent their water-drawer, and he let down his bucket. He said: glad tidings! here is a youth. And they hid him as merchandise, And Allah was the Knower of that which they worked.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And there came a caravan of travellers; they sent their water-drawer, and he let down his bucket (into the well). He said: "What good news! Here is a boy." So they hid him as merchandise (a slave). And Allah was the All-Knower of what they did.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: A caravan passed by, and they sent their water-carrier. He lowered his bucket, and said, “Good news. Here is a boy.” And they hid him as merchandise. But God was aware of what they did.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And a caravan came, and they sent their water drawer to draw water. As he let down his bucket in the well he (observed Joseph) and cried out: "This is good news. There is a boy." They concealed him, considering him as part of their merchandise, while Allah was well aware of what they did.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And there came a caravan of travelers and they sent their water-drawer, and he let down his bucket (into the well). He said: "What good news! Here is a boy." So they hid him as merchandise (a slave). And Allah was the All-Knower of what they did.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And there came a caravan, and they sent their waterdrawer. He let down his pail (into the pit). He said: Good luck! Here is a youth. And they hid him as a treasure, and Allah was Aware of what they did.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: There came a caravan, and they sent their water-drawer, who let down his bucket. ‘Good news!’ he said. ‘This is a young boy!’ So they hid him as [a piece of] merchandise, and Allah knew best what they were doing.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Thereafter travelers came, and sent their waterman. And when he had let down his pail, (he cried:) 'Rejoice, a boy' Then they concealed him among their merchandise, but Allah knew what they did.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And there came a company of travelers; then they sent their water drawer, and he let down his bucket. He said, "Good news! Here is a boy." And they concealed him, [taking him] as merchandise; and Allah was knowing of what they did.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: A caravan came by and sent their water carrier out to the well. When he drew out Joseph in his bucket, he shouted, "Glad news, a young boy!" The people of the caravan hid him amongst their belongings. God knows well what they do.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And there came travellers and they sent their water-drawer and he let down his bucket. He said: O good news! this is a youth; and they concealed him as an article of merchandise, and Allah knew what they did.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: And there came a caravan of travellers and they sent their water-drawer to draw water from the well. He let down his bucket into the well and he exclaimed, "Oh, what a lucky find, here is a boy!" They hid him like a piece of merchandise, but God knew well what they did.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then there came a caravan of travellers: they sent their water-carrier (for water), and he let down his bucket (into the well)... He said: "Ah there! Good news! Here is a (fine) young man!" So they concealed him as a treasure! But Allah knoweth well all that they do!

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The Egyptian who bought him instructed his wife: "House him honourably. He may be of use to us. We may even adopt him as a son." So, We firmly established Joseph in the land, and taught him the interpretation of dreams. God dominated in his affairs, though most men do not know.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: And the Egyptian who purchased him said to his wife, “Keep him honourably – we may derive some benefit due to him or we may adopt him as our son”; and this is how we established Yusuf in the land, and that We might teach him how to interpret events; and Allah is Dominant upon His works, but most men do not know.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He that bought him, being of Egypt, said to his wife, 'Give him goodly lodging, and it may be that he will profit us, or we may take him for our own son.' So We established Joseph in the land, and that We might teach him the interpretation of tales. God prevails in His purpose, but most men know not.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And he who bought him in Misr said unto his wife: make his dwelling honourable: belike he may profit us or we may take him as a son. And Thus We made a place for Yusuf in the land, and it was in order that We may teach him the interpretation of discourses. And Allah is Dominant in His purpose, but most of men know not.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And he (the man) from Egypt who bought him, said to his wife: "Make his stay comfortable, may be he will profit us or we shall adopt him as a son." Thus did We establish Yusuf (Joseph) in the land, that We might teach him the interpretation of events. And Allah has full power and control over His Affairs, but most of men know not.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: The Egyptian who bought him said to his wife, “Take good care of him; he may be useful to us, or we may adopt him as a son.” We thus established Joseph in the land, to teach him the interpretation of events. God has control over His affairs, but most people do not know.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: The man from Egypt who bought him said to his wife: "Take good care of him, possibly he might be of benefit to us or we might adopt him as a son." Thus We found a way for Joseph to become established in that land and in order that We might teach him to comprehend the deeper meaning of things. Allah has full power to implement His design although most people do not know that.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And he (the man) from Egypt who bought him, said to his wife: "Make his stay comfortable, maybe he will profit us or we shall adopt him as a son." Thus did We establish Yusuf in the land, that We might teach him the interpretation of events. And Allah has full power and control over His affairs, but most of men know not.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And he of Egypt who purchased him said unto his wife: Receive him honourably. Perchance he may prove useful to us or we may adopt him as a son. Thus we established Joseph in the land that We might teach him the interpretation of events. And Allah was predominant in His career, but most of mankind know not.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The man from Egypt who had bought him said to his wife, ‘Give him an honourable place [in the household]. Maybe he will be useful to us, or we may adopt him as a son.’ Thus We established Joseph in the land and that We might teach him the interpretation of dreams. Allah has [full] command of His affairs, but most people do not know.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: The Egyptian that bought him said to his wife: 'Make his stay honorable. He may benefit us, or take him for our son' As such We established Joseph in the land, so that We might teach him the interpretation of visions. Allah prevails in His affairs, though most people do not know.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And the one from Egypt who bought him said to his wife, "Make his residence comfortable. Perhaps he will benefit us, or we will adopt him as a son." And thus, We established Joseph in the land that We might teach him the interpretation of events. And Allah is predominant over His affair, but most of the people do not know.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Egyptian who bought him said to his wife, "Be kind to him, perhaps he will be of some benefit to us or we may adopt him." Thus, We settled Joseph in the land so that We could teach him the interpretation of dreams. God has full control over His affairs but most people do not know.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And the Egyptian who bought him said to his wife: Give him an honorable abode, maybe he will be useful to us, or we may adopt him as a son. And thus did We establish Yusuf in the land and that We might teach him the interpretation of sayings; and Allah is the master of His affair, but most people do not know.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: The Egyptian who bought him said to his wife, "Lodge him honourably, he may prove of benefit to us, or we may even adopt him as our son." Thus We established Joseph in the land, so that We might teach him the true meaning of events. God has power over all things. However, most people do not know this.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: The man in Egypt who bought him, said to his wife: "Make his stay (among us) honourable: may be he will bring us much good, or we shall adopt him as a son." Thus did We establish Joseph in the land, that We might teach him the interpretation of stories (and events). And Allah hath full power and control over His affairs; but most among mankind know it not.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When he reached the prime of life We gave him wisdom and knowledge. Thus We reward those who are good.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And when he was fully grown, We gave him judgment and knowledge. Even so We recompense the good-doers.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And when he reached his maturity We vouchsafed unto him judgement and knowledge; and Thus We recompense the well-doers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And when he [Yusuf (Joseph)] attained his full manhood, We gave him wisdom and knowledge (the Prophethood), thus We reward the Muhsinun (doers of good - see V. 2:112).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: When he reached his maturity, We gave him wisdom and knowledge. We thus reward the righteous.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And when Joseph reached the age of maturity, We granted him judgement and knowledge. Thus do We reward those who do good.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And when he [Yusuf] attained his full manhood, We gave him wisdom and knowledge (the prophethood), thus We reward the doers of good.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And And when he reached his prime We gave him wisdom and knowledge. Thus We reward the good.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When he came of age, We gave him judgement and [sacred] knowledge, and thus do We reward the virtuous.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And when he reached maturity, We bestowed on him judgment and knowledge. As such We recompense those who do good.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And when Joseph reached maturity, We gave him judgment and knowledge. And thus We reward the doers of good.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When he attained maturity, God gave him strength, wisdom and knowledge. Thus, do We reward those who do good.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And when he had attained his maturity, We gave him wisdom and knowledge: and thus do We reward those who do good.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: And when he reached maturity, We bestowed on him right judgement and knowledge. Thus We reward those who do good.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: When Joseph attained His full manhood, We gave him power and knowledge: thus do We reward those who do right.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: But she in whose house he resided wished to seduce him and, closing the doors, said: "Come into me. "God forbid!" he said; "he is my master who has approved my stay. Surely those who act wrongly do not prosper."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Now the woman in whose house he was solicited him, and closed the doors on them. 'Come,' she said, 'take me!' 'God be my refuge,' he said. 'Surely my lord has given me a goodly lodging. Surely the evildoers do not prosper.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And she in whose house he was, solicited him against himself; and she fastened the doors, and said: come on, O thou! He said: Allah be my refuge: verily he is my lord; he hath made me a goodly dwelling; verily the wrong-doers fare not well.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him (to do an evil act), she closed the doors and said: "Come on, O you." He said: "I seek refuge in Allah (or Allah forbid)! Truly, he (your husband) is my master! He made my stay agreeable! (So I will never betray him). Verily, the Zalimun (wrong and evil-doers) will never be successful."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: She in whose house he was living tried to seduce him. She shut the doors, and said, “I am yours.” He said, “God forbid! He is my Lord. He has given me a good home. Sinners never succeed.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And it so happened that the lady in whose house Joseph was living, sought to tempt him to herself, and one day bolting the doors she said: "Come on now!" Joseph answered: "May Allah grant me refuge! My Lord has provided an honourable abode for me (so how can I do something so evil)? Such wrong-doers never prosper."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him (to do an evil act), and she closed the doors and said: "Come on, O you." He said: "I seek refuge in Allah! Truly, he is my Rabb! He made my living in a great comfort! Verily, the wrongdoers will never be successful."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And she, in whose house he was, asked of him an evil act. She bolted the doors and said: Come! He said: I seek refuge in Allah! Lo! he is my lord, who hath treated me honourably. Lo! wrong-doers never prosper.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The woman in whose house he was, solicited him. She closed the doors and said, ‘Come!!’ He said, ‘God forbid! Indeed He is my Lord; He has given me a good abode. Indeed the wrongdoers are not felicitous.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him and closed the doors saying: 'Come' 'In Allah is my refuge' he replied. 'My Lord has made my dwelling a good one. Harmdoers never prosper'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him. She closed the doors and said, "Come, you." He said, "[I seek] the refuge of Allah. Indeed, he is my master, who has made good my residence. Indeed, wrongdoers will not succeed."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: His master's wife then tried to seduce him. She locked the doors and said to him, "Come on." He said, "I seek refuge in God who has given me a good place of shelter. The unjust will certainly have no happiness."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And she in whose house he was sought to make himself yield (to her), and she made fast the doors and said: Come forward. He said: I seek Allah's refuge, surely my Lord made good my abode: Surely the unjust do not prosper.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: However, the woman in whose house he lived, wanted to seduce him. One day she bolted the doors and said, "Come!" He replied, "God forbid! Truly [your husband] is my master and has treated me honourably. Wrongdoers certainly never prosper."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: But she in whose house he was, sought to seduce him from his (true) self: she fastened the doors, and said: "Now come, thou (dear one)!" He said: "Allah forbid! truly (thy husband) is my lord! he made my sojourn agreeable! truly to no good come those who do wrong!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: But the woman desired him, and he would have desired her but for the indication he received from his Lord. This was so that We may avert both evil and lechery from him, for he was one of Our chosen devotees.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: For she desired him; and he would have taken her, but that he saw the proof of his Lord. So was it, that We might turn away from him evil and abomination; he was one of Our devoted servants.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And assuredly she besought him, and he would have besoughther were it not that he had seen the argument of his Lord. Thus We did, in order that We might avert from him all evil and indecency; verily he was of our bondmen single-hearted.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And indeed she did desire him and he would have inclined to her desire, had he not seen the evidence of his Lord. Thus it was, that We might turn away from him evil and illegal sexual intercourse. Surely, he was one of Our chosen, guided slaves.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: She desired him, and he desired her, had he not seen the proof of his Lord. It was thus that We diverted evil and indecency away from him. He was one of Our loyal servants.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And she advanced towards him, and had Joseph not perceived a sign from his Lord he too would have advanced towards her. Thus was Joseph shown a sign from his Lord that We might avert from him all evil and indecency, for indeed he was one of Our chosen servants.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And indeed she did desire him, and he would have inclined to her desire, had he not seen the evidence of his Lord. Thus it was, that We might turn away from him evil and immoval sins. Surely, he was one of Our Mukhlasin servants.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: She verily desired him, and he would have desired her if it had not been that he saw the argument of his Lord. Thus it was, that We might ward off from him evil and lewdness. Lo! he was of Our chosen slaves.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: She certainly made for him; and he would have made for her [too] had he not beheld the proof of his Lord. So it was, that We might turn away from him all evil and indecency. He was indeed one of Our dedicated servants.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: She desired him, had he not been shown the proof of his Lord he would have taken her. But We turned him away from evil and abomination, for he was one of Our sincere worshipers.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And she certainly determined [to seduce] him, and he would have inclined to her had he not seen the proof of his Lord. And thus [it was] that We should avert from him evil and immorality. Indeed, he was of Our chosen servants.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: She was determined to have him and were it not for his faith in God, he would certainly have yielded to her. Thus did We protect him from evil and indecency. He was certainly one of Our sincere servants.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And certainly she made for him, and he would have made for her, were it not that he had seen the manifest evidence of his Lord; thus (it was) that We might turn away from him evil and indecency, surely he was one of Our sincere servants.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: She started towards him, and he would have succumbed to her, if he had not seen a sign from his Lord -- We did this in order to keep evil and indecency away from him, for he was truly one of Our chosen servants.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: And (with passion) did she desire him, and he would have desired her, but that he saw the evidence of his Lord: thus (did We order) that We might turn away from him (all) evil and shameful deeds: for he was one of Our servants, sincere and purified.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Both of them raced to the door, and she (grabbed and) rent his shirt from behind. They met her lord outside the door. "There is no other penalty for a man," said she, "who wanted to outrage your wife but imprisonment or grievous punishment."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They raced to the door; and she tore his shirt from behind. They encountered her master by the door. She said, 'What is the recompense of him who purposes evil against thy folk, but that he should be imprisoned, or a painful chastisement?'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And the twain raced to the door, and she rent his shirt from behind, And the twain met her master at the door. She said: What is the meed of him who intended evil toward thy house hold except that he be imprisoned, or a torment afflictive?

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So they raced with one another to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back. They both found her lord (i.e. her husband) at the door. She said: "What is the recompense (punishment) for him who intended an evil design against your wife, except that he be put in prison or a painful torment?"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: As they raced towards the door, she tore his shirt from behind. At the door, they ran into her husband. She said, “What is the penalty for him who desired to dishonor your wife, except imprisonment or a painful punishment?”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then both of them rushed to the door, each seeking to get ahead of the other, and she tore Joseph's shirt from behind. Then both of them found the husband of the lady at the door. Seeing him she said: "What should be the punishment of him who has foul designs on your wife except that he should be imprisoned or subjected to painful chastisement?"

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: So they raced with one another to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back. They both found her master (i.e. her husband) at the door. She said: "What is the recompense (punishment) for him who intended an evil design against your wife, except that he be put in prison or a painful torment"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And they raced with one another to the door, and she tore his shirt from behind, and they met her lord and master at the door. She said: What shall be his reward, who wisheth evil to thy folk, save prison or a painful doom?

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They raced to the door, and she tore his shirt from behind, and they ran into her husband at the door. She said, ‘What is to be the requital of him who has evil intentions for your wife except imprisonment or a painful punishment?’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They raced to the door and she tore his shirt from behind. And by the door, they met her husband whereupon she said: 'What is the recompense of one whose intent is evil against your people other than being imprisoned, or sternly punished'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And they both raced to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back, and they found her husband at the door. She said, "What is the recompense of one who intended evil for your wife but that he be imprisoned or a painful punishment?"

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: She chased him to the door, grabbed him from behind, and tore off his shirt. Suddenly, they were face to face with her husband. (Looking accusingly at Joseph) she asked her husband, "What punishment is more fitting for those who have evil desires towards your household other than imprisonment and painful torment?"

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And they both hastened to the door, and she rent his shirt from behind and they met her husband at the door. She said: What is the punishment of him who intends evil to your wife except imprisonment or a painful chastisement?

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: They both ran to the door and, in the struggle, she tore his shirt at the back. They found her husband at the door. She cried, "Shall not the man who wished to violate your wife be thrown into prison or sternly punished?"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So they both raced each other to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back: they both found her lord near the door. She said: "What is the (fitting) punishment for one who formed an evil design against thy wife, but prison or a grievous chastisement?"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (Joseph) said: "It was she who wanted to seduce me." And a witness from her family testified: "If the shirt is torn from the front then the woman is speaking the truth, and he is a liar.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Said Yusuf, “It was she who lured me, that I may not guard myself” – and a witness from her own household testified; “If his shirt is torn from the front, then the woman is truthful and he has spoken incorrectly.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Said he, 'It was she that solicited me'; and a witness of her folk bore witness, 'If his shirt has been torn from before then she has spoken truly, and he is one of the liars;

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: it is she who solicited me against myself And a witness from her own household bare witness: if his shirt be rent in front, then she speaketh the truth and he is of the liars.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: He [Yusuf (Joseph)] said: "It was she that sought to seduce me," - and a witness of her household bore witness (saying): "If it be that his shirt is torn from the front, then her tale is true and he is a liar!

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “It was she who tried to seduce me.” A witness from her household suggested: “If his shirt is torn from the front: then she has told the truth, and he is the liar.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "It is she who was trying to tempt me to herself." And a witness belonging to her own household testified (on grounds of circumstantial evidence): "If his shirt is torn from the front, then she is telling the truth and he is a liar.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: He [Yusuf] said: "It was she that sought to seduce me;" and a witness of her household bore witness (saying): "If it be that his shirt is torn from the front, then her tale is true and he is a liar!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (Joseph) said: She it was who asked of me an evil act. And a witness of her own folk testified: If his shirt is torn from before, then she speaketh truth and he is of the liars.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘It was she who solicited me.’ A witness of her own household testified [thus]: ‘If his shirt is torn from the front, she tells the truth and he lies.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He (Joseph) said: 'It was she who sought to seduce me' and a witness (an infant) of her people bore witness, saying: 'If his shirt is torn from the front, she is speaking the truth and he is one of the liars,

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Joseph] said, "It was she who sought to seduce me." And a witness from her family testified. "If his shirt is torn from the front, then she has told the truth, and he is of the liars.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph said, "It was she who tried to seduce me." Someone from the household in confirmation of Joseph's statement said, "If his shirt it torn from the front, she has spoken the truth and he is lying,

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: She sought to make me yield (to her); and a witness of her own family bore witness: If his shirt is rent from front, she speaks the truth and he is one of the liars:

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph said, "It was she who sought to seduce me." One of her household testified, "If his shirt is torn at the front then she is speaking the truth, and he is lying.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: He said: "It was she that sought to seduce me - from my (true) self." And one of her household saw (this) and bore witness, (thus):- "If it be that his shirt is rent from the front, then is her tale true, and he is a liar!

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When the husband saw the shirt torn at the back, he said: "Surely this is a woman's ruse, and the wiles of women are great.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: When he saw his shirt was torn from behind he said, 'This is of your women's guile; surely your guile is great.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: So when he saw his shirt rent from behind, he said: verily it is of the guile of ye women; verily the guile of ye women is mighty.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So when he (her husband) saw his [(Yusuf's (Joseph)] shirt torn at the back; (her husband) said: "Surely, it is a plot of you women! Certainly mighty is your plot!

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And when he saw that his shirt was torn from the back, he said, “This is a woman's scheme. Your scheming is serious indeed.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: So when the husband saw Joseph's shirt torn from behind he exclaimed: "Surely, this is one of the tricks of you women; your tricks are indeed great.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: So when he (her husband) saw his [Yusuf`s] shirt torn at the back, he (her husband) said: "Surely, it is a plot of you women! Certainly mighty is your plot!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: So when he saw his shirt torn from behind, he said: Lo! this is of the guile of you women. Lo! the guile of you is very great.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: So when he saw that his shirt was torn from behind, he said, ‘This is [a case] of you women’s guile! Your guile is indeed great!

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And when he saw his shirt torn at the back, he said: 'This is one of your (women's) guiles. Your guile, (O woman), is great indeed!

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So when her husband saw his shirt torn from the back, he said, "Indeed, it is of the women's plan. Indeed, your plan is great.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When the master saw that Joseph's shirt was torn from behind, he told his wife, "This is some of your womanly guile in which you are certainly skillful.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So when he saw his shirt rent from behind, he said: Surely it is a guile of you women; surely your guile is great:

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: So when he saw his shirt torn from behind [her husband] said, "This is the guile of you women. Your guile is great indeed.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So when he saw his shirt,- that it was torn at the back,- (her husband) said: "Behold! It is a snare of you women! truly, mighty is your snare!

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Ignore this affair, O Joseph; and you, O woman, ask forgiveness for your sin, for you were surely errant."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: “O Yusuf! Disregard this – and O woman! Seek forgiveness for your sin; indeed you are of the mistaken.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Joseph, turn away from this; and thou, woman, ask forgiveness of thy crime; surely thou art one of the sinners.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Yusuf! turn away therefrom; and, thou woman! ask forgiveness for thy sin; verily thou hast been of the guilty.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: "O Yusuf (Joseph)! Turn away from this! (O woman!) Ask forgiveness for your sin. Verily, you were of the sinful."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: “Joseph, turn away from this. And you, woman, ask forgiveness for your sin; you are indeed in the wrong.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph, disregard this. And you - woman - ask forgiveness for your sin, for indeed it is you who has been at fault."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: "O Yusuf! Turn away from this! (O woman!) Ask forgiveness for your sin, verily, you were of the sinful."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: O Joseph! Turn away from this, and thou, (O woman), ask forgiveness for thy sin. Lo! thou art of the faulty.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Joseph, let this matter alone, and you, woman, plead for forgiveness for your sin, for you have indeed been erring.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Joseph, turn away from this. And you, ask forgiveness for your sin. You are indeed one of the sinners'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Joseph, ignore this. And, [my wife], ask forgiveness for your sin. Indeed, you were of the sinful."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph, stay away from such affairs and you, woman, ask forgiveness for your sin; the guilt is yours."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: O Yusuf! turn aside from this; and (O my wife)! ask forgiveness for your fault, surely you are one of the wrong-doers.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph, overlook this: but you [wife], ask forgiveness for your sin, for you have done wrong."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "O Joseph, pass this over! (O wife), ask forgiveness for thy sin, for truly thou hast been at fault!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When she heard their slanderings, she sent for them and prepared a banquet, and gave each of them a knife (for paring fruit), and called (to Joseph): "Come out before them." When they saw him, the women were so wonderstruck they cut their hands, and exclaimed: "O Lord preserve us! He is no mortal but an honourable angel."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: And when she heard of their secret talk, she sent for them and prepared cushioned mattresses for them and gave a knife to each one of them and said to Yusuf, “Come out before them!” When the women saw him they praised him and cut their hands, and said, “Purity is to Allah – this is no human being; this is not but an honourable angel!”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: When she heard their sly whispers, she sent to them, and made ready for them a repast, then she gave to each one of them a knife. 'Come forth, attend to them,' she said. And when they saw him, they so admired him that they cut their hands, saying, 'God save us! This is no mortal; he is no other but a noble angel.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Then, when she heard of their cunning talk, she sent unto them a messenger, and got ready for them a cushioned Couch, and gave a knife to each of them. And she said: come forth to them. Then when they saw him, they were astonished at him, and they made a cut in their hands, and said: how perfect is God! no man is he: he is naught but an angel noble.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So when she heard of their accusation, she sent for them and prepared a banquet for them; she gave each one of them a knife (to cut the foodstuff with), and she said [(to Yusuf (Joseph)]: "Come out before them." Then, when they saw him, they exalted him (at his beauty) and (in their astonishment) cut their hands. They said: "How perfect is Allah (or Allah forbid)! No man is this! This is none other than a noble angel!"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And when she heard of their gossip, she invited them, and prepared for them a banquet, and she gave each one of them a knife. She said, “Come out before them.” And when they saw him, they marveled at him, and cut their hands. They said, “Good God, this is not a human, this must be a precious angel.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Hearing of their sly talk the chief's wife sent for those ladies, and arranged for them a banquet, and got ready couches, and gave each guest a knife. Then, while they were cutting and eating the fruit, she signalled Joseph: "Come out to them." When the ladies saw him they were so struck with admiration that they cut their hands, exclaiming: "Allah preserve us. This is no mortal human. This is nothing but a noble angel!"

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: So when she heard of their accusation, she sent for them and prepared a banquet for them; she gave each one of them a knife, and she said [to Yusuf]: "Come out before them." Then, when they saw him, they exalted him (at his beauty) and (in their astonishment) cut their hands. They said: "How perfect is Allah! No man is this! This is none other than a noble angel!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And when she heard of their sly talk, she sent to them and prepared for them a cushioned couch (to lie on at the feast) and gave to every one of them a knife and said (to Joseph): Come out unto them! And when they saw him they exalted him and cut their hands, exclaiming: Allah Blameless! This is no a human being. This is not other than some gracious angel.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When she heard of their machinations, she sent for them and arranged a repast, and gave each of them a knife, and said [to Joseph], ‘Come out before them.’ So when they saw him, they marvelled at him and cut their hands [absent-mindedly], and they said, ‘Good heavens! This is not a human being! This is but a noble angel!’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: When she heard of their sly whispers, she sent for them and prepared a banquet. To each she gave a knife, (then called Joseph saying:) 'Come and attend to them' When they saw him, they were so taken with him that they cut their hands, and said: 'Allah save us! This is no mortal, he is no other but a noble angel'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So when she heard of their scheming, she sent for them and prepared for them a banquet and gave each one of them a knife and said [to Joseph], "Come out before them." And when they saw him, they greatly admired him and cut their hands and said, "Perfect is Allah! This is not a man; this is none but a noble angel."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When she heard their gossiping, she invited them to her house for a banquet and gave a knife to each of them. Then she told Joseph to appear before them. When they saw Joseph, they were so amazed that they cut their hands and said, "Goodness gracious! He is not a mortal but is a charming angel!"

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So when she heard of their sly talk she sent for them and prepared for them a repast, and gave each of them a knife, and said (to Yusuf): Come forth to them. So when they saw him, they deemed him great, and cut their hands (in amazement), and said: Remote is Allah (from imperfection); this is not a mortal; this is but a noble angel.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: When she heard of their intrigues, she sent for them and prepared a party for them. She gave a knife to each of them [to cut fruits, etc.] and then asked Joseph to appear before them. When the women saw him, they were greatly amazed [at his beauty], and they cut their hands, exclaiming, "God preserve us! This is no human being but a noble angel!"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: When she heard of their malicious talk, she sent for them and prepared a banquet for them: she gave each of them a knife: and she said (to Joseph), "Come out before them." When they saw him, they did extol him, and (in their amazement) cut their hands: they said, "Allah preserve us! no mortal is this! this is none other than a noble angel!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (Joseph) prayed: "O Lord, dearer is prison than what they invite me to. Unless You turn their guiles away from me I shall succumb to their charms and thus become a pagan."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'My Lord, prison is dearer to me than that they call me to; yet if Thou turnest not from me their guile, then I shall yearn towards them, and so become one of the ignorant.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: my Lord: prison is dearer to me than that to which these women call me; and if Thou avertest not their guile from me should incline toward them and become of the Ignorant.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: He said:"O my Lord! Prison is more to my liking than that to which they invite me. Unless You turn away their plot from me, I will feel inclined towards them and be one (of those who commit sin and deserve blame or those who do deeds) of the ignorants."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “My Lord, prison is more desirable to me than what they call me to. Unless You turn their scheming away from me, I may yield to them, and become one of the ignorant.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "My Lord! I prefer imprisonment to what they ask me to do. And if You do not avert from me the guile of these women, I will succumb to their attraction and lapse into ignorance."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: He said: "O my Lord! Prison is dearer to me than that to which they invite me. Unless You turn away their plot from me, I will feel inclined towards them and be one of the ignorant."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: O my Lord! Prison is more dear than that unto which they urge me, and if Thou fend not off their wiles from me I shall incline unto them and become of the foolish.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘My Lord! The prison is dearer to me than to what they invite me. If You do not turn away their schemes from me, I will incline towards them and become one of the senseless.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He supplicated: 'Lord, prison is dearer to me than that to which they invite me. Yet if You do not shield me from their guile I shall yield to them and be one of the ignorant'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: He said, "My Lord, prison is more to my liking than that to which they invite me. And if You do not avert from me their plan, I might incline toward them and [thus] be of the ignorant."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph said, "Lord, prison is dearer to me than that which women want me to do. Unless You protect me from their guile, I shall be attracted to them in my ignorance".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: My Lord! the prison house is dearer to me than that to which they invite me; and if Thou turn not away their device from me, I will yearn towards them and become (one) of the ignorant.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph said, "O my Lord! I would prefer prison to what these women are inviting me to do. And if You do not avert their guile from me, I may yield to them and so become one of the ignorant."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: He said: "O my Lord! the prison is more to my liking than that to which they invite me: Unless Thou turn away their snare from me, I should (in my youthful folly) feel inclined towards them and join the ranks of the ignorant."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: And yet in spite of having seen these clear proofs they found it proper to incarcerate him for a time.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Then it seemed good to them, after they had seen the signs, that they should imprison him for a while.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Thereafter it occurred to them even after they had, the signs, to imprison him for a season.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Then it appeared to them, after they had seen the proofs (of his innocence) to imprison him for a time.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Then it occurred to them, after they had seen the signs, to imprison him for a while.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then it occurred to them to cast Joseph into prison for a while even though they had seen clear signs (of Joseph's innocence and of the evil ways of their ladies).

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Then it occurred to them, after they had seen the proofs (of his innocence), to imprison him for a time.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And it seemed good to them (the men-folk) after they had seen the signs (of his innocence) to imprison him for a time.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Then it appeared to them, after they had seen all the signs [of his innocence], that they should confine him for some time.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Then it seemed good to them, even after they had seen the signs, that they should imprison him for some time.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Then it appeared to them after they had seen the signs that al-'Azeez should surely imprison him for a time.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Even after Joseph had been found innocent of any crime, the King and his people decided to imprison him for an appointed time (so that people would forget the incident).

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: Then it occurred to them after they had seen the signs that they should imprison him till a time.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Yet, even after all the evidence they had seen, they thought it right to jail him for a time.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then it occurred to the men, after they had seen the signs, (that it was best) to imprison him for a time.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Two other youths were imprisoned along with him. Said one of them: "I dreamt that I was pressing grapes;" and the other: "I dreamt that I was carrying bread on my head, and the birds were pecking at it. You tell us the meaning of this. You seem to be a righteous man."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And there entered the prison with him two youths. Said one of them, 'I dreamed that I was pressing grapes. Said the other, 'I dreamed that I was carrying on my head bread, that birds were eating of. Tell us its interpretation; we see that thou art of the good-doers.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And there entered with him into the prison two pages. One of them said: verlly I saw myself pressing wine; and the other said: verily I saw myself carrying upon my head bread whereof the birds were eating. declare unto us the interpretation thereof, verily we see thee of the well-doers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And there entered with him two young men in the prison. One of them said: "Verily, I saw myself (in a dream) pressing wine." The other said: "Verily, I saw myself (in a dream) carrying bread on my head and birds were eating thereof." (They said): "Inform us of the interpretation of this. Verily, we think you are one of the Muhsinun (doers of good - see V. 2:112)."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Two youth entered the prison with him. One of them said, “I see myself pressing wine.” The other said, “I see myself carrying bread on my head, from which the birds are eating. Tell us their interpretation—we see that you are one of the righteous.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And with Joseph two other slaves entered the prison. One of them said: "I saw myself pressing wine in a dream"; and the other said: "I saw myself carrying bread on my head of which the birds were eating." Both said: "Tell us what is its interpretation; for we consider you to be one of those who do good."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And there entered with him two young men in the prison. One of them said: "Verily, I saw myself (in a dream) pressing wine." The other said: "Verily, I saw myself (in a dream) carrying bread on my head and birds were eating thereof." (They said): "Inform us of the interpretation of this. Verily, we think you are one of the doers of good."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And two young men went to prison with him. One of them said: I dreamed that I was pressing wine. The other said: I dreamed that I was carrying upon my head bread whereof the birds were eating. Announce unto us the interpretation, for we see thee of those good (at interpretation).

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: There entered the prison two youths along with him. One of them said, ‘I dreamt that I am pressing grapes.’ The other said, ‘I dreamt that I am carrying bread on my head from which the birds are eating.’ ‘Inform us of its interpretation,’ [they said], ‘for indeed we see you to be a virtuous man.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Two young men went to prison with him. One of them said: 'I saw (in a vision) that I was pressing grapes' And the other said: 'I saw (in a vision) that I was carrying bread upon my head, and that birds ate of it. Tell us its interpretation, for we can see you are among the good'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And there entered the prison with him two young men. One of them said, "Indeed, I have seen myself [in a dream] pressing wine." The other said, "Indeed, I have seen myself carrying upon my head [some] bread, from which the birds were eating. Inform us of its interpretation; indeed, we see you to be of those who do good."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Two young men were also sent to serve prison sentences (for different reasons). One of them said, "I had a dream in which I was brewing wine." The other one said, "In my dream I was carrying some bread on my head and birds were eating that bread." They asked Joseph if he would interpret their dreams. They said, "We believe you to be a righteous person."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And two youths entered the prison with him. One of them said: I saw myself pressing wine. And the other said: I saw myself carrying bread on my head, of which birds ate. Inform us of its interpretation; surely we see you to be of the doers of good.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Two young men entered the prison along with him. One of them said, "I saw myself [in a dream] I was pressing wine." The other said, "I dreamed I was carrying bread on my head from which the birds were eating. Tell us their meaning; for we see that you are one who does good [to all]."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Now with him there came into the prison two young men. Said one of them: "I see myself (in a dream) pressing wine." said the other: "I see myself (in a dream) carrying bread on my head, and birds are eating, thereof." "Tell us" (they said) "The truth and meaning thereof: for we see thou art one that doth good (to all)."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (Joseph) answered: "I will give you its interpretation before the food you are served arrives. This knowledge is one of the things my Lord has taught me. I have given up the religion of those who do not believe in God and deny the life to come.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Said Yusuf, “The food which you get will not reach you, but I will tell you the interpretation of this before it comes to you; this is one of the sciences my Lord has taught me; indeed I did not accept the religion of the people who do not believe in Allah and are deniers of the Hereafter.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'No food shall come to you for your sustenance, but ere it comes to you I shall tell you its interpretation. That I shall tell you is of what God has taught me. I have forsaken the creed of a people who believe not in God and who moreover are unbelievers in the world to come.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: there will not come to you any food wherewith ye are provided but I shall have declared unto the interpretation thereof ere it cometh unto you. that is of that which my Lord hath taught me; verily I have abandoned the creed of a people who believe not in Allah and who in the Hereafter are disbelievers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: He said: "No food will come to you (in wakefulness or in dream) as your provision, but I will inform (in wakefulness) its interpretation before it (the food) comes. This is of that which my Lord has taught me. Verily, I have abandoned the religion of a people that believe not in Allah and are disbelievers in the Hereafter (i.e. the Kan'aniun of Egypt who were polytheists and used to worship sun and other false deities).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “No food is served to you, but I have informed you about it before you have received it. That is some of what my Lord has taught me. I have forsaken the tradition of people who do not believe in God; and regarding the Hereafter, they are deniers.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "I will inform you about the interpretation of the dreams before the arrival of the food that is sent to you. This knowledge is part of what I have been taught by my Lord. I have renounced the way of those who do not believe in Allah, and who deny the Hereafter,

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
