translation.text: He said: "No food will come to you as your provision, but I will inform its interpretation before it comes. This is of that which my Lord has taught me. Verily, I have abandoned the religion of a people that believe not in Allah and are disbelievers in the Hereafter."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: The food which ye are given (daily) shall not come unto you but I shall tell you the interpretation ere it cometh unto you. This is of that which my Lord hath taught me. Lo! I have forsaken the religion of folk who believe not in Allah and are disbelievers in the Hereafter.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘Before the meals you are served come to you I will inform you of its interpretation. That is among things my Lord has taught me. Indeed, I renounce the creed of the people who have no faith in Allah and who [also] disbelieve in the Hereafter.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He said: 'Before any food comes to feed either of you, I will give you its interpretation. That which I will tell you has been taught to me by Allah. I reject the belief of a nation who do not believe in Allah and disbelieve in the Everlasting Life.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: He said, "You will not receive food that is provided to you except that I will inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. That is from what my Lord has taught me. Indeed, I have left the religion of a people who do not believe in Allah, and they, in the Hereafter, are disbelievers.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: (Joseph) said, "To prove that my interpretation of your dream is true, I can tell you what kind of food you will receive even before it comes to you. My Lord has given me such talents. I have given up the tradition of the people who do not believe in God and the Day of Judgment

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: There shall not come to you the food with which you are fed, but I will inform you both of its interpretation before it comes to you; this is of what my Lord has taught me; surely I have forsaken the religion of a people who do not believe in Allah, and they are deniers of the hereafter:

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph said to them, "I shall inform you of the interpretation of your dreams before your meal is brought to you. This is a part of the knowledge that my Lord has taught me. I have renounced the religion of the people who do not believe in God and who deny the Hereafter.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: He said: "Before any food comes (in due course) to feed either of you, I will surely reveal to you the truth and meaning of this ere it befall you: that is part of the (duty) which my Lord hath taught me. I have (I assure you) abandoned the ways of a people that believe not in Allah and that (even) deny the Hereafter.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: And (Joseph) asked the man he knew would be released: "Remember me to your lord;" but Satan made him forget to mention this to his lord, and Joseph remained in prison for a number of years.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: And of the two, Yusuf said to the one whom he sensed would be released, “Remember me, in the company of your lord”; so Satan caused him to forget to mention Yusuf to his lord, he therefore stayed in prison for several years more.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Then he said to the one he deemed should be saved of the two, 'Mention me in thy lord's presence.' But Satan caused him to forget to mention him to his master, so that he continued in the prison for certain years.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And he said to one of them who he imagined would be saved: mention me in the presence of thy lord. Then the Satan caused him to forget to mention him to his lord, so that he tarried in the prison several years.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And he said to the one whom he knew to be saved: "Mention me to your lord (i.e. your king, so as to get me out of the prison)." But Shaitan (Satan) made him forget to mention it to his Lord [or Satan made [(Yusuf (Joseph)] to forget the remembrance of his Lord (Allah) as to ask for His Help, instead of others]. So [Yusuf (Joseph)] stayed in prison a few (more) years.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And he said to the one he thought would be released, “Mention me to your master.” But Satan caused him to forget mentioning him to his master, so he remained in prison for several years.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And Joseph said to the one of the two prisoners who he knew would be set free: "Mention me in your lord's presence." But Satan caused him to forget mentioning this to his lord (the ruler of Egypt) and so Joseph languished in prison for several years.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And he said to the one whom he knew to be saved: "Mention me to your king." But Shaytan made him forget to mention it to his master. So [Yusuf] stayed in prison a few (more) years.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And he said unto him of the twain who he knew would be released: Mention me in the presence of thy lord. But Satan caused him to forget to mention it to his lord, so he (Joseph) stayed in prison for some years.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Then he said to the one whom he knew would be delivered from among the two: ‘Mention me to your master.’ But Satan caused him to forget mentioning [it] to his master. So he remained in the prison for several years.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And he said to the one of the two who he knew would be saved: 'Mention me in the presence of your lord' But satan made him forget to mention him to his master, so that he remained in prison for a certain number years.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And he said to the one whom he knew would go free, "Mention me before your master." But Satan made him forget the mention [to] his master, and Joseph remained in prison several years.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph asked the one, whom he knew would not be executed, to mention his case to his Lord. Satan caused that man to forget all about Joseph and his case. Thus, Joseph remained in prison for some years.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And he said to him whom he knew would be delivered of the two: Remember me with your lord; but the Shaitan caused him to forget mentioning (it) to his lord, so he remained in the prison a few years.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: He said to the one he thought would be saved, "Mention me to your master." However Satan made him forget to mention him to his master, and so Joseph remained in prison for a number of years.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: And of the two, to that one whom he consider about to be saved, he said: "Mention me to thy lord." But Satan made him forget to mention him to his lord: and (Joseph) lingered in prison a few (more) years.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Then the servant, who of the two had been released, remembering (Joseph), said: "I will give you its interpretation; let me go for it."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Then said the one who had been delivered, remembering after a time, 'I will myself tell you its interpretation; so send me forth.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Then the one of the twain, who was saved, and now recollected himself after a period, said: I, even I, shall declare unto you the interpretation thereof; so send me forth.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Then the man who was released (one of the two who were in prison), now at length remembered and said: "I will tell you its interpretation, so send me forth."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: The one who was released said, having remembered after a time, “I will inform you of its interpretation, so send me out.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then of the two prisoners, the one who had been set free, now remembered, after the lapse of a long period, what Joseph had said. He said: "I will tell you the interpretation of this dream; just send me (to Joseph in prison)."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Then the man who was released, now at length remembered and said: "I will tell you its interpretation, so send me forth."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And he of the two who was released, and (now) at length remembered, said: I am going to announce unto you the interpretation, therefore send me forth.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Said the one of the two who had been delivered, remembering [Joseph] after a long time: ‘I will inform you of its interpretation; so let me go [to meet Joseph in the prison].’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: After all that time, the one of the two who had been saved remembered, he said: 'I will interpret it for you, so let me go'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: But the one who was freed and remembered after a time said, "I will inform you of its interpretation, so send me forth."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The man who was in prison with Joseph and who was released, recalled after so many years Joseph's (ability to interpret dreams) and said, "I can tell you the meaning of this dream if you allow me to go (to the prison and ask the man who knows the meanings of dreams)."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And of the two (prisoners) he who had found deliverance and remembered after a long time said: I will inform you of its interpretation, so let me go:

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Then one of the two men who had been released and who, after a long time, remembered, said, "I shall tell you its interpretation; therefore, give me leave to go [to Joseph in prison]."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: But the man who had been released, one of the two (who had been in prison) and who now bethought him after (so long) a space of time, said: "I will tell you the truth of its interpretation: send ye me (therefore)."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (And coming to the prison) he said: "O Joseph the truthful, tell us (the meaning of) seven fat cows being devoured by seven lean ones, and seven green ears of corn and seven seared, that I may go back to the people and tell them."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: “O Yusuf! O truthful one! Explain for us the seven healthy cows which seven lean cows were eating and the seven green ears of corn and seven others dry, so I may return to the people, possibly they may come to know.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: 'Joseph, thou true man, pronounce to us regarding seven fat kine, that seven lean ones were devouring, seven green ears of corn, and seven withered; haply I shall return to the men, haply they will know.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Yusuf, O saint! give an answer unto us in regard to seven fat kine which seven lean ones are devouring and seven green corn-ears and seven others dry; haply may return unto the people; haply they may learn.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: (He said): "O Yusuf (Joseph), the man of truth! Explain to us (the dream) of seven fat cows whom seven lean ones were devouring, and of seven green ears of corn, and (seven) others dry, that I may return to the people, and that they may know."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: “Joseph, O man of truth, inform us concerning seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green spikes, and others dried up, so that I may return to the people, so that they may know.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then he went to Joseph and said to him: "Joseph, O truthfulness incarnate, tell the true meaning of the dream in which seven fat cows are devoured by seven lean ones; and there are seven green ears of corn and seven others dry and withered so that I may return to the people and they may learn."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: (He said): "O Yusuf, the man of truth! Explain to us seven fat cows whom seven lean ones were devouring, and seven green ears of corn, and (seven) others dry, that I may return to the people, and that they may know."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (And when he came to Joseph in the prison, he exclaimed): Joseph! O thou truthful one! Expound for us the seven fat kine which seven lean were eating and the seven green ears of corn and other (seven) dry, that I may return unto the people, so that they may know.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: ‘Joseph,’ [he said], ‘O truthful one, give us your opinion concerning seven fat cows who are eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green ears and [seven] others dry, that I may return to the people so that they may know [the truth of the matter].’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: (He said:) 'Joseph, the truthful, tell us of the seven fatted cows that were devoured by seven lean ones also of the seven green ears of corn and the other seven which were withered, so that I can go back to the people and then they will then know'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [He said], "Joseph, O man of truth, explain to us about seven fat cows eaten by seven [that were] lean, and seven green spikes [of grain] and others [that were] dry - that I may return to the people; perhaps they will know [about you]."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: (He went to the prison) and said to Joseph, "You are a man of truth. Would you tell me the meaning of a dream in which seven fat cows eat up seven lean ones and the meaning of seven green ears of corn and seven dry ones? I hope you can tell me the right meaning and save people from confusion."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: Yusuf! O truthful one! explain to us seven fat kine which seven lean ones devoured, and seven green ears and (seven) others dry, that I may go back to the people so that they may know.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: "O truthful Joseph!" he said, "Tell us the meaning of a dream in which seven fat cows are being eaten by seven lean ones, and there are seven green ears of corn and seven others which are dry, so that I may return to my people and inform them."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "O Joseph!" (he said) "O man of truth! Expound to us (the dream) of seven fat kine whom seven lean ones devour, and of seven green ears of corn and (seven) others withered: that I may return to the people, and that they may understand."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: He said: "Sow as usual for seven years, and after reaping leave the corn in the ears, except the little you need for food.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'You shall sow seven years after your wont; what you have harvested leave in the ear, excepting a little whereof you eat.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: ye shall sow seven years as is your went; and that which ye reap leave in its ears, except a little whereof ye may eat.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [(Yusuf (Joseph)] said: "For seven consecutive years, you shall sow as usual and that (the harvest) which you reap you shall leave in ears, (all) - except a little of it which you may eat.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “You will farm for seven consecutive years. But whatever you harvest, leave it in its spikes, except for the little that you eat.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "You will cultivate consecutively for seven years. Leave in the ears all that you have harvested except the little out of which you may eat.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: [Yusuf] said: "For seven consecutive years, you shall sow as usual and that which you reap you shall leave it in the ears, (all) except a little of it which you may eat."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: Ye shall sow seven years as usual, but that which ye reap, leave it in the ear, all save a little which ye eat.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘You will sow for seven consecutive years. Then leave in the ear whatever [grain] you harvest, except a little that you eat.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He replied: 'You shall sow for seven years as is your way. Leave in the ear (of corn) you reap, except a little which you eat.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Joseph] said, "You will plant for seven years consecutively; and what you harvest leave in its spikes, except a little from which you will eat.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: (Joseph) said, "Cultivate your lands for seven years as usual and preserve the produce with its ears each year except the little amount that you will consume.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: You shall sow for seven years continuously, then what you reap leave it in its ear except a little of which you eat.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph said, "You shall sow for seven consecutive years as usual, but leave in the ear the harvest that you reap, except for a little which you may eat.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (Joseph) said: "For seven years shall ye diligently sow as is your wont: and the harvests that ye reap, ye shall leave them in the ear,- except a little, of which ye shall eat.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The king said: "Bring him to me. So when the messenger came to Joseph, he said: "Go back to your lord and ask him: 'How fare the women who had cut their hands?' My Lord is cognisant of their guile."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: And the king said, “Bring him to me”; so when the bearer came to him, Yusuf said, “Return to your lord and ask him what is the status of the women who had cut their hands; indeed my Lord knows their deception.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: The king said, 'Bring him to me!' And when the messenger came to him, he said, 'Return unto thy lord, and ask of him, "What of the women who cut their hands?" Surely my Lord has knowledge of their guile.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And the king said: bring him Unto me. Then, when the messenger came to him, he said: return to thy lord, and ask him, what about the women who cut their hands! verily my Lord is the Knower of their guile.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And the king said: "Bring him to me." But when the messenger came to him, [Yusuf (Joseph)] said: "Return to your lord and ask him, 'What happened to the women who cut their hands? Surely, my Lord (Allah) is Well-Aware of their plot. 

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: The king said, “Bring him to me.” And when the envoy came to him, he said, “Go back to your master, and ask him about the intentions of the women who cut their hands; my Lord is well aware of their schemes.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: The king said: "Bring this man to me." But when the royal messenger came to Joseph he said: "Go back to your master and ask him about the case of the women who had cut their hands. Surely my Lord has full knowledge of their guile."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And the king said: "Bring him to me." But when the messenger came to him, [Yusuf] said: "Return to your king and ask him, `What happened to the women who cut their hands Surely, my Lord (Allah) is Well-Aware of their plot."'

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And the king said: Bring him unto me. And when the messenger came unto him, he (Joseph) said: Return unto thy lord and ask him what was the case of the women who cut their hands. Lo! my Lord knoweth their guile.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The king said, ‘Bring him to me!’ When the messenger came to him, he said, ‘Go back to your master, and ask him about the affair of women who cut their hands. My Lord is indeed well aware of their stratagems.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: The king said: 'Bring him before me' But when the king's envoy came to him, he said: 'Go back to your lord and ask him: "What about the women who cut their hands. Indeed, my Lord knows their guile'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And the king said, "Bring him to me." But when the messenger came to him, [Joseph] said, "Return to your master and ask him what is the case of the women who cut their hands. Indeed, my Lord is Knowing of their plan."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The King ordered his people to bring Joseph into his presence. When the messenger came to Joseph, he (Joseph) said, "Ask your master about the women who cut their hands. My Lord knows all about their guile".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And the king said: Bring him to me. So when the messenger came to him, he said: Go back to your lord and ask him, what is the case of the women who cut their hands; surely my Lord knows their guile.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: The king said, "Bring him to me." When the king's messenger came to Joseph, he said, "Go back to your master and ask him about the women who cut their hands: my Lord knows well their guile."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So the king said: "Bring ye him unto me." But when the messenger came to him, (Joseph) said: "Go thou back to thy lord, and ask him, 'What is the state of mind of the ladies who cut their hands'? For my Lord is certainly well aware of their snare."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The king asked the women: "What was the affair of seducing Joseph?" "God preserve us," they said; "we know no evil against him." The wife of the minister said: "The truth has now come out. It was I who desired to seduce him, but he is indeed a man of virtue." --

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: The king said, “O women! What was your role when you tried to entice Yusuf?” They answered, “Purity is to Allah – we did not find any immorality in him”; said the wife of the governor, “Now the truth is out; it was I who tried to entice him, and indeed he is truthful.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: 'What was your business, women,' he said, 'when you solicited Joseph?' 'God save us!' they said. 'We know no evil against him.' The Governor's wife said, 'Now the truth is at last discovered; I solicited him; he is a truthful man.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: What was the matter with you when ye solicited Yusuf against himself! They said: how perfect is God! we knew not of any evil against him. The wife of the Aziz said: how hath the truth come to light, even I, solicited him against himself, and verily he is of the truth-tellers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: (The King) said (to the women): "What was your affair when you did seek to seduce Yusuf (Joseph)?" The women said: "Allah forbid! No evil know we against him!" The wife of Al-'Aziz said: "Now the truth is manifest (to all), it was I who sought to seduce him, and he is surely of the truthful."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “What was the matter with you, women, when you tried to seduce Joseph?” They said, “God forbid! We knew of no evil committed by him.” The governor’s wife then said, “Now the truth is out. It was I who tried to seduce him, and he is telling the truth.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Thereupon the king asked the women: "What happened when you sought to tempt Joseph?" They said: "Allah forbid! We found no evil in him." The chief's wife said: "Now the truth has come to light. It was I who sought to tempt him. He is indeed truthful."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: (The king) said (to the women): "What was your affair when you did seek to seduce Yusuf" The women said: "Allah forbid! No evil know we against him!" The wife of the `Aziz said: "Now the truth is manifest (to all); it was I who sought to seduce him, and he is surely of the truthful. "

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He (the king) (then sent for those women and) said: What happened when ye asked an evil act of Joseph? They answered: Allah Blameless! We know no evil of him. Said the wife of the ruler: Now the truth is out. I asked of him an evil act, and he is surely of the truthful.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The king said, ‘What was your business, women, when you solicited Joseph?’ They said, ‘Heaven be praised! We know of no evil in him.’ The prince’s wife said, ‘Now the truth has come to light! It was I who solicited him, and he is indeed telling the truth.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 'What was your business, women' he asked, 'when you solicited Joseph' 'Allah save us' they replied. 'We know no evil against him' The Governor's wife said: 'The truth has been discovered at last; I solicited him; he is among the truthful.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Said [the king to the women], "What was your condition when you sought to seduce Joseph?" They said, "Perfect is Allah! We know about him no evil." The wife of al-'Azeez said, "Now the truth has become evident. It was I who sought to seduce him, and indeed, he is of the truthful.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The King asked the women about their attempt to seduce Joseph. They replied, "God forbid! We do not know of any bad in Joseph." The wife of the King said, "Now the truth has come to light. It was I who tried to seduce Joseph. He is, certainly, a truthful man."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: How was your affair when you sought Yusuf to yield himself (to you)? They said: Remote is Allah (from imperfection), we knew of no evil on his part. The chief's wife said: Now has the truth become established: I sought him to yield himself (to me), and he is most surely of the truthful ones.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: The king asked the women, "What was the truth of the affair in which you tried to seduce Joseph?" The women said, "God forbid! We know no evil of him." The wife of the nobleman said, "The truth has now come to light. It was I who tried to seduce him; he is surely an honest man."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (The king) said (to the ladies): "What was your affair when ye did seek to seduce Joseph from his (true) self?" The ladies said: "Allah preserve us! no evil know we against him!" Said the 'Aziz's wife: "Now is the truth manifest (to all): it was I who sought to seduce him from his (true) self: He is indeed of those who are (ever) true (and virtuous).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (At this Joseph remarked:) "From this (the Minister) should know that I did not betray him in his absence, and that God does not surely let the wiles of those who betray ever succeed.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Said Yusuf, “I did this so that the governor may realise that I did not betray him behind his back, and Allah does not let the deceit of betrayers be successful.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: 'That, so that he may know I betrayed him not secretly, and that God guides not the guile of the treacherous.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: that did in order that he may know that I betrayed him not in secret, and that Allah guideth not the guile of betrayers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [Then Yusuf (Joseph) said: "I asked for this enquiry] in order that he (Al-'Aziz) may know that I betrayed him not in secret. And, verily! Allah guides not the plot of the betrayers.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: “This is that he may know that I did not betray him in secret, and that God does not guide the scheming of the betrayers.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "I did this so that he [i.e. the chief) may know that I did not betray him in his absence, and that Allah does not allow the design of the treacherous to succeed.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: [Then Yusuf said: "I asked for this inquiry] in order that he may know that I betrayed him not in (his) absence." And, verily, Allah guides not the plot of the betrayers.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (Then Joseph said: I asked for) this, that he (my lord) may know that I betrayed him not in secret, and that surely Allah guideth not the snare of the betrayers.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: [Joseph said], [‘I initiated] this [inquiry], that he may know that I did not betray him in his absence, and that Allah does not further the schemes of the treacherous.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: This (I have done) so that he will know I did not secretly betray him, and that Allah does not guide the guile of the treacherous.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: That is so al-'Azeez will know that I did not betray him in [his] absence and that Allah does not guide the plan of betrayers.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: (Joseph said), "This proves that I was not disloyal to the King in his absence. God does not grant success to the efforts of disloyal people.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: This is that he might know that I have not been unfaithful to him in secret and that Allah does not guide the device of the unfaithful.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: "From this," said Joseph, "[The nobleman] should know that I did not betray him in his absence, and that God does not guide the plotting of the treacherous.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "This (say I), in order that He may know that I have never been false to him in his absence, and that Allah will never guide the snare of the false ones.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When the king heard this he said: "Bring him to me. I shall take him in my special service." When he had talked to him, he said: "Today you are established in a rank of trust with us."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: The king said, 'Bring him to me! I would attach him to my person.' Then, when he had spoken with him, he said, 'Today thou art established firmly in our favour and in our trust.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And the king said: bring him unto me I will single him out for myself Then when he spake unto him, he said: verily thou art to-day with us placed high, intrusted.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And the king said: "Bring him to me that I may attach him to my person." Then, when he spoke to him, he said: "Verily, this day, you are with us high in rank and fully trusted."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: The king said, “Bring him to me, and I will reserve him for myself.” And when he spoke to him, he said, “This day you are with us established and secure.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: The king said: "Bring him to me. I will select him exclusively for my own service." So when Joseph spoke to him the king said: "You are now one of established position, fully-trusted by us."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And the king said: "Bring him to me that I may attach him to my person." Then, when he spoke to him, he said: "Verily, this day, you are with us high in rank and fully trusted."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And the king said: Bring him unto me that I may attach him to my person. And when he had talked with him he said: Lo! thou art to-day in our presence established and trusted.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The king said, ‘Bring him to me, I will make him my favourite.’ Then, when he had spoken with him, he said, ‘Indeed today [onwards] you will be honoured and trustworthy with us.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: The king said: 'Bring him before me. I will assign him to myself' And when he had spoken with him he said: 'Today, you are firmly established in both our favor and trust'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And the king said, "Bring him to me; I will appoint him exclusively for myself." And when he spoke to him, he said, "Indeed, you are today established [in position] and trusted."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The King ordered his men to bring Joseph before him. He wanted to grant him a high office. The King said to Joseph, "From now on you will be an honored and trusted person among us".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And the king said: Bring him to me, I will choose him for myself. So when he had spoken with him, he said: Surely you are in our presence today an honorable, a faithful one.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: The king said, "Bring him to me. I will take him for my special service." And when he had spoken to him, he said, "From now on you will dwell with us, honoured and trusted."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So the king said: "Bring him unto me; I will take him specially to serve about my own person." Therefore when he had spoken to him, he said: "Be assured this day, thou art, before our own presence, with rank firmly established, and fidelity fully proved!

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "Appoint me over the granaries of the land," (he said); "I shall be a knowledgeable keeper."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: Said Yusuf, “Appoint me over the treasures of the earth; indeed I am a protector, knowledgeable.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'Set me over the land's storehouses; I am a knowing guardian.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: set me over the store houses of the land; verily I shall be a keeper knowing.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [Yusuf (Joseph)] said: "Set me over the storehouses of the land; I will indeed guard them with full knowledge" (as a minister of finance in Egypt, in place of Al-'Aziz who was dead at that time).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “Put me in charge of the storehouses of the land; I am honest and knowledgeable.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "Place me in charge of the treasures of the land. I am a good keeper and know my task well."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: [Yusuf] said: "Set me over the storehouses of the land; I will indeed guard them with full knowledge."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: Set me over the storehouses of the land. Lo! I am a skilled custodian.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘Put me in charge of the country’s granaries. I am indeed fastidious [and]well-informed.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He (Joseph) said: 'Give me charge of the storehouses of the land, I am a knowledgeable guardian'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Joseph] said, "Appoint me over the storehouses of the land. Indeed, I will be a knowing guardian."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph said, "Put me in charge of the treasuries of the land. I know how to manage them."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: Place me (in authority) over the treasures of the land, surely I am a good keeper, knowing well.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph said, "Place in my charge the storehouses of the land; for I am a good and knowledgeable custodian."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (Joseph) said: "Set me over the store-houses of the land: I will indeed guard them, as one that knows (their importance)."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Thus We gave Joseph authority in the land so that he lived wherever he liked. We bestow Our favours on whomsoever We please, and do not allow the reward of those who are good to go waste.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: And this is how We gave Yusuf the control over that land; to stay in it wherever he pleased; We may convey Our mercy to whomever We will, and We do not waste the wages of the righteous.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: So We established Joseph in the land, to make his dwelling there wherever he would. We visit with Our mercy whomsoever We will, and We leave not to waste the wage of the good-doers.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Thus We established Yusuf in the land so that he might settle therein wherever he listed. We bestow of Our mercy on whomsoever We will, and We waste not the hire of the well-doers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Thus did We give full authority to Yusuf (Joseph) in the land, to take possession therein, as when or where he likes. We bestow of Our Mercy on whom We please, and We make not to be lost the reward of Al-Muhsinun (the good doers - see V. 2:112).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And thus We established Joseph in the land, to live therein wherever he wished. We touch with Our mercy whomever We will, and We never waste the reward of the righteous.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Thus did We establish Joseph in the land so that he could settle wherever he pleased. We bestow favour, out of Our Mercy, on whomsoever We please, and We do not cause the reward of those who do good to go to waste.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Thus did We give full authority to Yusuf in the land, to take possession therein, when or where he likes. We bestow of Our mercy on whom We will, and We make not to be lost the reward of the good doers.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Thus gave We power to Joseph in the land. He was the owner of it where he pleased. We reach with Our mercy whom We will. We lose not the reward of the good.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: That is how We established Joseph in the land that he may settle in it wherever he wished. We confer Our mercy on whomever We wish, and We do not waste the reward of the virtuous.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And as such We established Joseph in the land to live wherever he liked. We bestow Our Mercy on whom We will, and We never waste the wage of therighteous.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And thus We established Joseph in the land to settle therein wherever he willed. We touch with Our mercy whom We will, and We do not allow to be lost the reward of those who do good.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Thus, We settled Joseph in the land to live wherever he wanted. We grant a due share of Our mercy to whomever We want and We do not ignore the reward of the righteous ones.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And thus did We give to Yusuf power in the land-- he had mastery in it wherever he liked; We send down Our mercy on whom We please, and We do not waste the reward of those who do good.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Thus We caused Joseph to be established in a position of authority in the land. He could dwell therein wherever he pleased. We bestow Our mercy on whomever We please, and We do not allow the reward of the righteous to go to waste.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Thus did We give established power to Joseph in the land, to take possession therein as, when, or where he pleased. We bestow of our Mercy on whom We please, and We suffer not, to be lost, the reward of those who do good.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The brothers of Joseph came (to Egypt) and visited him. He recognised them, though they did not recognise him.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And the brethren of Joseph came, and entered unto him, and he knew them, but they knew him not.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And the brethren of Yusuf came and entered unto him, and he recognized them, while they recognized him not.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And Yusuf's (Joseph) brethren came and they entered unto him, and he recognized them, but they recognized him not.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And Joseph's brothers came, and entered into his presence. He recognized them, but they did not recognize him.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And Joseph's brothers came to Egypt and presented themselves before him. He recognized them, but they did not know him.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And Yusuf's brethren came and they entered unto him, and he recognized them, but they recognized him not.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And Joseph's brethren came and presented themselves before him, and he knew them but they knew him not.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: [After some years] the brothers of Joseph came and entered his presence. He recognized them, but they did not recognize him.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Joseph's brothers came and presented themselves before him. He recognized them, but they did not know him.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And the brothers of Joseph came [seeking food], and they entered upon him; and he recognized them, but he was to them unknown.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph's brothers came to him. When they entered his court, he recognized them. They did not know him.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And Yusuf's brothers came and went in to him, and he knew them, while they did not recognize him.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph's brothers arrived and presented themselves before him. He recognized them, but they did not know him.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then came Joseph's brethren: they entered his presence, and he knew them, but they knew him not.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When he had supplied their provisions, he said to them: "Bring your (half) brother with you. Have you not seen that I have given full measure, and that I am the best of hosts?

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: When he had equipped them with their equipment be said, 'Bring me a certain brother of yours from your father. Do you not see that I fill up the measure, and am the best of hosts?

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And when he had furnished them with their furnishing, he said: bring unto me a brother of your from your father behold ye not that I give full measure and that am the best of entertainers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And when he had furnished them forth with provisions (according to their need), he said: "Bring me a brother of yours from your father; (he meant Benjamin). See you not that I give full measure, and that I am the best of the hosts?

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: When he provided them with their provisions, he said, “Bring me a brother of yours from your father. Do you not see that I fill up the measure, and I am the best of hosts?”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And when he had prepared for them their provisions, Joseph said: "Bring to me your other brother from your father. Do you not see that I give full measure and am most hospitable?

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And when he furnished them with their provisions, he said: "Bring me a brother of yours from your father. See you not that I give full measure, and that I am the best of the hosts"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And when he provided them with their provision he said: Bring unto me a brother of yours from your father. See ye not that I fill up the measure and I am the best of hosts?

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When he had furnished them with their provision, he said, ‘Bring me a brother that you have through your father. Do you not see that I give the full measure and that I am the best of hosts?

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And when he had given them their provisions, he said: 'Bring me a certain brother from your father. Do you not see that I give just measure and am the bestof hosts?

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And when he had furnished them with their supplies, he said, "Bring me a brother of yours from your father. Do not you see that I give full measure and that I am the best of accommodators?

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When he had furnished them with provisions, he said, "Next time, bring me your other brother from your father. As you can see, I give each of you a certain amount of grain; I am a polite host.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And when he furnished them with their provision, he said: Bring to me a brother of yours from your father; do you not see that I give full measure and that I am the best of hosts?

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: When he had made provision for them, he told them, "Bring me your brother on your father's side. Do you not see that I give you full measure and that I am the best of hosts?

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: And when he had furnished them forth with provisions (suitable) for them, he said: "Bring unto me a brother ye have, of the same father as yourselves, (but a different mother): see ye not that I pay out full measure, and that I do provide the best hospitality?

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Then he ordered his servants: "Put their money back in their packs: They may find it on reaching home, and perhaps come again."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said to his pages, 'Put their merchandise in their saddlebags; haply they will recognize it when they have turned to their people; haply they will return.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And he said to his pages: place their goods in their packs, haply they will recognize them when they reach back to their household: haply they will return.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And [Yusuf (Joseph)] told his servants to put their money (with which they had bought the corn) into their bags, so that they might know it when they go back to their people, in order that they might come back.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said to his servants, “Put their goods in their saddlebags; perhaps they will recognize them when they return to their families, and maybe they will come back.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And Joseph said to his servants: "Put surreptitiously in their packs the goods they had given in exchange for corn." Joseph did so expecting that they would find it when they returned home. Feeling grateful for this generosity, they might be inclined to return to him.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And [Yusuf] told his servants to put their money into their bags, so that they might know it when they go back to their people; in order that they might come again.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said unto his young men: Place their merchandise in their saddlebags, so that they may know it when they go back to their folk, and so will come again.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said to his servants, ‘Put their money [back] into their saddlebags. Maybe they will recognize it when they return to their folks, and maybe they will come back [again].’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Then he said to his attendants: 'Put their merchandise in their saddlebags, hopefully they will recognize it when they return to their people. Perhaps they will come back'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And [Joseph] said to his servants, "Put their merchandise into their saddlebags so they might recognize it when they have gone back to their people that perhaps they will [again] return."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Then Joseph told his people to put his brothers' money back into their bags so that perhaps they would recognize it, when at home, and come back to Egypt once again.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And he said to his servants: Put their money into their bags that they may recognize it when they go back to their family, so that they may come back.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Joseph said to his servants, "Put their money back into their saddlebags, so that they will recognize it when they return home to their family; thus they may come back."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: And (Joseph) told his servants to put their stock-in-trade (with which they had bartered) into their saddle-bags, so they should know it only when they returned to their people, in order that they might come back.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: He replied: "Should I trust you with him as I did his brother? But God is the best of guardians, and most merciful of all."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'And shall I entrust him to you otherwise than as I entrusted before his brother to you? Why, God is the best guardian, and He is the most merciful of the merciful.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: I intrust you with him only as I intrusted you with his brother aforetime; Allah is the best Guard, and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: He said: "Can I entrust him to you except as I entrusted his brother [Yusuf (Joseph)] to you aforetime? But Allah is the Best to guard, and He is the Most Merciful of those who show mercy."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “Shall I trust you with him, as I trusted you with his brother before? God is the Best Guardian, and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: The father said: "Shall I trust you with regard to him as I had trusted you earlier with regard to his brother? Allah is the Best Protector and is the Most Merciful."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: He said: "Can I entrust him to you except as I entrusted his brother [Yusuf] to you aforetime But Allah is the Best to guard, and He is the Most Merciful of those who show mercy."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: Can I entrust him to you save as I entrusted his brother to you aforetime? Allah is better at guarding, and He is the Most Merciful of those who show mercy.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘Should I not trust you with him just as I trusted you with his brother before? Yet Allah is the best of protectors, and He is the most merciful of merciful ones.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He replied: 'Am I to trust you with him as I once trusted you with his brother? Why, Allah is the Best of guardians, and He is the Most Merciful of theMerciful'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: He said, "Should I entrust you with him except [under coercion] as I entrusted you with his brother before? But Allah is the best guardian, and He is the most merciful of the merciful."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Jacob replied, "How can I trust you after what happened to his brother before? Only God is the best Protector. His mercy is far greater than that of others."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: He said: I cannot trust in you with respect to him, except as I trusted in you with respect to his brother before; but Allah is the best Keeper, and He is the most Merciful of the merciful ones.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: He replied, "Am I to trust you with him as I once trusted you with his brother? But God is the best of guardians, the Most Merciful of all."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: He said: "Shall I trust you with him with any result other than when I trusted you with his brother aforetime? But Allah is the best to take care (of him), and He is the Most Merciful of those who show mercy!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When they came to Joseph he made his brother his guest, and said: "I am your brother. So do not grieve for what they had done."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: And when they entered in the company Yusuf, he seated his brother close to him and said, “Be assured, I really am your brother – therefore do not grieve for what they do.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And when they entered unto Joseph, he said, taking his brother into his arms, 'I am thy brother; so do not despair of that they have done.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And when they entered unto Yusuf, he betook his full brother unto himself, and said: verily I am thine own brother Yusuf, so sorrow not over that which they have been working.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And when they went in before Yusuf (Joseph), he betook his brother (Benjamin) to himself and said: "Verily! I am your brother, so grieve not for what they used to do."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And when they entered into the presence of Joseph, he embraced his brother, and said, “I am your brother; do not be saddened by what they used to do.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: When they presented themselves before Joseph, he took his brother aside to himself and said: "Verily I am your own brother Joseph; so do not grieve over the manner they have treated you."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And when they went in before Yusuf, he took his brother (Binyamin) to himself and said: "Verily, I am your brother, so grieve not for what they used to do."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And when they went in before Joseph, he took his brother unto him, saying: Lo! I, even I, am thy brother, therefore sorrow not for what they did.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When they entered into the presence of Joseph, he set his brother close to himself, and said, ‘Indeed I am your brother, so do not sorrow for what they used to do.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: When they presented themselves before Joseph, he took his brother in his arms, and said: 'I am your brother. Do not grieve at what they did'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And when they entered upon Joseph, he took his brother to himself; he said, "Indeed, I am your brother, so do not despair over what they used to do [to me]."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When they entered Joseph's court, he gave lodging to his own brother (Benjamin) and said, "I am your brother. Do not feel sad about whatever they had done".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And when they went in to Yusuf. he lodged his brother with himself, saying: I am your brother, therefore grieve not at what they do.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: When they presented themselves before Joseph, he took his brother [Benjamin] aside. He said, "I am your brother, so do not feel distressed about whatever they have been doing."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Now when they came into Joseph's presence, he received his (full) brother to stay with him. He said (to him): "Behold! I am thy (own) brother; so grieve not at aught of their doings."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When he had given them their provisions he put his goblet in his brother's saddle-bag. Then a crier announced: "O men of the caravan, you are thieves."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Then, when he had equipped them with their equipment, he put his drinking-cup into the saddlebag of his brother. Then a herald proclaimed, 'Ho, cameleers, you are robbers!'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And when he had furnished them with their furnishing; he placed the drinking-cup in his brother's pack. - Thereafter a crier cried: O caravan! verily ye are thieves.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So when he had furnished them forth with their provisions, he put the (golden) bowl into his brother's bag, then a crier cried: "O you (in) the caravan! Surely, you are thieves!"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Then, when he provided them with their provisions, he placed the drinking-cup in his brother’s saddlebag. Then an announcer called out, “O people of the caravan, you are thieves.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then, while Joseph was having their provisions loaded, he put his drinking-cup in his brother's saddlebag. And then a herald cried: "Travellers, you are thieves."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: So when he furnished them forth with their provisions, he put the bowl in his brother's bag. Then a crier cried: "O you (in) the caravan! Surely, you are thieves!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And when he provided them with their provision, he put the drinking-cup in his brother's saddlebag, and then a crier cried: O camel-riders! Lo! ye are surely thieves!

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When he had furnished them with their provision, he put the drinking-cup into his brother’s saddlebag. Then a herald shouted: ‘O [men of the] caravan! You are indeed thieves!’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And when he had given them their provisions, he hid a drinkingcup in his brother's saddlebag. Then a herald called out after them: 'Cameleers, you are thieves!'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So when he had furnished them with their supplies, he put the [gold measuring] bowl into the bag of his brother. Then an announcer called out, "O caravan, indeed you are thieves."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When he had furnished them with provisions, he placed the King's drinking cup in his own brother's baggage. Then someone shouted, "People of the caravan, you are thieves!"

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So when he furnished them with their provisions, (someone) placed the drinking cup in his brother's bag. Then a crier cried out: O caravan! you are most surely thieves.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: And when he had given them their provisions, he placed a drinking-cup in his brother's pack. Then a crier called out after them, "Men of the caravan! You have committed theft!"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: At length when he had furnished them forth with provisions (suitable) for them, he put the drinking cup into his brother's saddle-bag. Then shouted out a crier: "O ye (in) the caravan! behold! ye are thieves, without doubt!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "We cannot find the master's goblet. Whoever comes up with it will be given a camel-load of grain; I vouch for it."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They said, 'We are missing the king's goblet. Whoever brings it shall receive a camel's load; that I guarantee.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: They said: we miss the king's cup; and for him who bringeth it shall be a camel-load; and thereof I am a guarantor.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: They said: "We have missed the (golden) bowl of the king and for him who produces it is (the reward of) a camel load; I will be bound by it."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: They said, “We are missing the king’s goblet. Whoever brings it will have a camel-load; and I personally guarantee it.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: The officials said: "We have lost the king's cup." (And their chief added): "He who brings it shall have a camel-load of provisions, I guarantee that."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: They said: "We have lost the bowl of the king and for him who produces it is (the reward of) a camel load; and I will be bound by it."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: They said: We have lost the king's cup, and he who bringeth it shall have a camel-load, and I (said Joseph) am answerable for it.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They said, ‘We miss the king’s goblet.’ ‘Whoever brings it shall have a camel-load [of grain],’ [said the steward], ‘I will guarantee that.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 'We are missing the goblet of the king' he replied. 'Whosoever restores it shall have a camelload, that I guarantee'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: They said, "We are missing the measure of the king. And for he who produces it is [the reward of] a camel's load, and I am responsible for it."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: They were told, "The King's drinking cup is missing and whoever brings it will receive a camel's load of grain. I promise you that".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: They said: We miss the king's drinking cup, and he who shall bring it shall have a camel-load and I am responsible for it.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: "We miss the royal measuring bowl," he replied. "He who brings it shall have a camel-load of corn. I pledge my word for it."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: They said: "We miss the great beaker of the king; for him who produces it, is (the reward of) a camel load; I will be bound by it."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "What should be the punishment," they were asked, "in case you are liars?"

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They said, 'And what shall be its recompense if you are liars?'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: They said: what shall be the meed of him, if ye are found liars!

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: They [Yusuf's (Joseph) men] said: "What then shall be the penalty of him, if you are (proved to be) liars."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: They said, “What shall be his punishment, if you are lying?”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: The officials said: "If you are lying, what will be the penalty for him who has stolen?"

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: They said: "What then shall be the penalty of him, if you are (proved to be) liars."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: They said: And what shall be the penalty for it, if ye prove liars?

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They said, ‘What shall be its requital if you [prove to] be lying?’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They said: 'What shall be the recompense, if you prove to be lying'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: The accusers said, "Then what would be its recompense if you should be liars?"

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Egyptians said, "What do you suggest should be the punishment for the thief, if it is proved that you are lying?"

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: They said: But what shall be the requital of this, if you are liars?

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: The Egyptians asked them, "And if we find that you are lying, what penalty shall we mete out to you?"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (The Egyptians) said: "What then shall be the penalty of this, if ye are (proved) to have lied?"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "The punishment for that (should be)," they said, "that he in whose luggage it is found should be held as punishment. This is how we repay the wrong-doers."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They said, 'This shall be its recompense -- in whoever's saddlebag the goblet is found, he shall be its recompense. So we recompense the evildoers.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: They said: his meed shall be that he, in whose pack it is found, shall himself be recompense thereof. Thus we reccmpense the wrong- doers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: They [Yusuf's (Joseph) brothers] said: "The penalty should be that he, in whose bag it is found, should be held for the punishment (of the crime). Thus we punish the Zalimun (wrong-doers, etc.)!"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: They said, “His punishment, if it is found in his bag: he will belong to you. Thus we penalize the guilty.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: They replied: "He in whose saddlebag the cup is found, he himself shall be its recompense." Thus do we punish the wrong-doers.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: They [Yusuf's brothers] said: "His penalty should be that he, in whose bag it is found, should be held for the punishment (of the crime). Thus we punish the wrongdoers!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: They said: The penalty for it! He in whose bag (the cup) is found, he is the penalty for it. Thus we requite wrong-doers.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They said, ‘The requital for it shall be that he in whose saddlebag it is found shall give himself over as its requital. Thus do we requite the wrongdoers.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They replied: 'Its recompense in whosoever's saddle bag it is found, he shall be its recompense. As such we punish the harmdoers'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [The brothers] said, "Its recompense is that he in whose bag it is found - he [himself] will be its recompense. Thus do we recompense the wrongdoers."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Joseph's brothers replied, "In whosoever baggage it is found, that person will be your bondsman. Thus is the punishment of the unjust."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: They said: The requital of this is that the person in whose bag it is found shall himself be (held for) the satisfaction thereof; thus do we punish the wrongdoers.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: They replied, "The penalty should be that he in whose saddlebag it is found, should be held [as bondman] to atone for the crime. That is how we punish the wrongdoers."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: They said: "The penalty should be that he in whose saddle-bag it is found, should be held (as bondman) to atone for the (crime). Thus it is we punish the wrong-doers!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: So he searched their saddle-bags before his brother's, then produced the cup from his brother's bag. That is how We planned an excuse for Joseph, for under the law of the king he could not detain his brother unless God so willed. We raise the status of whom We please. Over every man of knowledge there is one more knowing.

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: So he first searched their bags before his brother’s bag, then removed it from his brother’s bag; this was the plan We had taught Yusuf; he had no right to take his brother by the king’s law, except if Allah wills; We may raise in ranks whomever We will; and above every possessor of knowledge is another scholar.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: So he made beginning with their sacks, before his brother's sack, then he pulled it out of his brother's sack. So We contrived for Joseph's sake; he could not have taken his brother, according to the king's doom, except that God willed. Whomsoever We will, We raise in rank; over every man of knowledge is One who knows.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Then he began with their sacks before the sack of his brother; then he brought it forth from his brothers sack. In this wise We contrived for Yusuf. He was not one to take his brother by the law of the king, except that Allah willed. We exalt in degrees whomsoever We will, and above every knowing one is a Knower.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So he [Yusuf (Joseph)] began (the search) in their bags before the bag of his brother. Then he brought it out of his brother's bag. Thus did We plan for Yusuf (Joseph). He could not take his brother by the law of the king (as a slave), except that Allah willed it. (So Allah made the brothers to bind themselves with their way of "punishment, i.e. enslaving of a thief.") We raise to degrees whom We please, but over all those endowed with knowledge is the All-Knowing (Allah).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: So he began with their bags, before his brother's bag. Then he pulled it out of his brother’s bag. Thus We devised a plan for Joseph; he could not have detained his brother under the king’s law, unless God so willed. We elevate by degrees whomever We will; and above every person of knowledge, there is one more learned.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then Joseph began searching their bags before searching his own brother's bag. Then he brought forth the drinking-cup from his brother's bag. Thus did We contrive to support Joseph. He had no right, according to the religion of the king (i.e. the law of Egypt), to take his brother, unless Allah so willed. We exalt whomsoever We will over others by several degrees. And above all those who know is the One Who truly knows.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: So he [Yusuf] began (the search) in their bags before the bag of his brother. Then he brought it out of his brother's bag. Thus did We plan for Yusuf. He could not take his brother by the law of the king (as a slave), except that Allah willed it. We raise to degrees whom We will, but over all those endowed with knowledge is the All-Knowing (Allah).

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Then he (Joseph) began the search with their bags before his brother's bag, then he produced it from his brother's bag. Thus did We contrive for Joseph. He could not have taken his brother according to the king's law unless Allah willed. We raise by grades (of mercy) whom We will, and over every lord of knowledge there is one more knowing.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Then he began with their sacks, before [opening] his brother’s sack. Then he took it out from his brother’s sack. Thus did We devise for Joseph’s sake. He could not have held his brother under the king’s law unless Allah willed [otherwise]. We raise in rank whomever We please, and above every man of knowledge is One who knows best.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He searched their bags before his brother's and then took out the goblet from his brother's bag. As such We directed Joseph. By the king's law he had no right to seize his brother unless Allah willed otherwise. We raise whom We will in rank; over every knowledgeable person is One who knows.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So he began [the search] with their bags before the bag of his brother; then he extracted it from the bag of his brother. Thus did We plan for Joseph. He could not have taken his brother within the religion of the king except that Allah willed. We raise in degrees whom We will, but over every possessor of knowledge is one [more] knowing.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: They searched their baggage before that of Joseph's real brother where at last they found it. Thus, We showed Joseph how to plan this; he would not have been able to take his brother under the King's law unless God had wanted it to be so. We give a high rank to whomever We want. Over every knowledgeable person is one more knowing.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So he began with their sacks before the sack of his brother, then he brought it out from his brother's sack. Thus did We plan for the sake of Yusuf; it was not (lawful) that he should take his brother under the king's law unless Allah pleased; We raise the degrees of whomsoever We please, and above every one possessed of knowledge is the All-knowing one.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: He [the herald] searched their bags before his brother's and then took out the cup from his brother's bag. In this way, We devised a plan on behalf of Joseph. He could not have detained his brother under the King's law, unless God so willed. We exalt whoever We please: but above those who have knowledge there is One all knowing.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So he began (the search) with their baggage, before (he came to) the baggage of his brother: at length he brought it out of his brother's baggage. Thus did We plan for Joseph. He could not take his brother by the law of the king except that Allah willed it (so). We raise to degrees (of wisdom) whom We please: but over all endued with knowledge is one, the All-Knowing.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Said the brothers: "If he has stolen (no wonder), his brother had stolen before." But Joseph kept this secret and did not disclose it to them, and said (to himself): "You are worse in the degree of evil, for God knows better of what you allege."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: They said, “If he steals, then indeed his brother has stolen before”; so Yusuf kept this in his heart and did not reveal it to them; he replied within himself, “In fact, you are in a worse position; and Allah well knows the matters you fabricate.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: They said, 'If he is a thief, a brother of his was a thief before.' But Joseph secreted it in his soul and disclosed it not to them, saying, 'You are in a worse case; God knows very well what you are describing.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: They said: if he stealeth, then surely a brother of him hath stolen afore. But Yusuf concealed it in himself, and discovered it not unto them. He said: ye are in evil plight, and Allah is the Best Knower of that which ye ascribe.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: They [(Yusuf's (Joseph) brothers] said: "If he steals, there was a brother of his [Yusuf (Joseph)] who did steal before (him)." But these things did Yusuf (Joseph) keep in himself, revealing not the secrets to them. He said (within himself): "You are in worst case, and Allah knows best the truth of what you assert!"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: They said, “If he has stolen, a brother of his has stolen before.” But Joseph kept it to himself, and did not reveal it to them. He said, “You are in a worse situation, and God is Aware of what you allege.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: They said: "No wonder that he steals for a brother of his stole before." But Joseph kept his reaction to himself without disclosing the truth to them. He merely said to himself: "You are an evil lot. Allah knows well the truth of the accusation that you are making against me (to my face)."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: They [Yusuf's brothers] said: "If he steals, there was a brother of his [Yusuf] who did steal before (him). " But these things did Yusuf keep in himself, revealing not the secrets to them. He said (within himself): "You are in an evil situation, and Allah is the Best Knower of that which you describe!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: They said: If he stealeth, a brother of his stole before. But Joseph kept it secret in his soul and revealed it not unto them. He said (within himself): Ye are in worse case, and Allah knoweth best (the truth of) that which ye allege.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: They said, ‘If he has stolen [there is no wonder]; a brother of his had stolen before.’ Thereupon Joseph kept the matter to himself and he did not disclose it to them. He said, ‘You are in a worse state! And Allah knows best what you allege.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: They said: 'If he is a thief know then that a brother of his has committed theft before him' But Joseph kept it secret and did not reveal it to them. He said:'You are in a worse position. And Allah knows well what you describe'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: They said, "If he steals - a brother of his has stolen before." But Joseph kept it within himself and did not reveal it to them. He said, "You are worse in position, and Allah is most knowing of what you describe."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: (Joseph's) brothers said, "It's no wonder that he steals; a brother of his had stolen before him." Joseph noted their remarks, but did not utter a word. He said (to himself), "You are in a worse position. God knows best what you allege."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: They said: If he steal, a brother of his did indeed steal before; but Yusuf kept it secret in his heart and did not disclose it to them. He said: You are in an evil condition and Allah knows best what you state.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: They said, "If he is a thief, a brother of his had [also] committed theft before him." But Joseph kept his secret and revealed nothing to them. He said [to himself], "Your deed was worse. God best knows the things you speak of."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: They said: "If he steals, there was a brother of his who did steal before (him)." But these things did Joseph keep locked in his heart, revealing not the secrets to them. He (simply) said (to himself): "Ye are the worse situated; and Allah knoweth best the truth of what ye assert!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "May God forgive us," he said, "if we hold any one but him with whom we found our property, or else we would be unjust."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'God forbid that we should take any other but him in whose possession we found the goods; for if we did so, we would be evildoers.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: He said: Allah forbid that we should take anyone but him with whom we found our stuff; verily then we should be the wrong-doers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: He said: "Allah forbid, that we should take anyone but him with whom we found our property. Indeed (if we did so), we should be Zalimun (wrong-doers)."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “God forbid that we should arrest anyone except him in whose possession we found our property; for then we would be unjust.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Joseph said: "Allah forbid that we should seize any except him with whom we found our good. Were we to do so, we would surely be one of the wrong-doers."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: He said: "Allah forbid, that we should take anyone but him with whom we found our property. Indeed (if we did so), we should be wrongdoers."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: Allah forbid that we should seize save him with whom we found our property; then truly we should be wrong-doers.

translation.author: Qarai
